awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Hexagonal Ferrite Thin Films for the High-Temperature Magnetoelectric Memory Effect
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The discovery and utilization of the dynamic coupling between the electric and magnetic fields - electromagnetic waves - has revolutionized human society, particularly in the wireless communications. The "static" couplings between the electric and magnetic fields in a material (e.g. switching the north and south poles of a magnet using an electric field) are expected to have major applications in compact and energy efficient information storage and processing, sensors, and actuators. These applications are desired since the demand for information storage and processing is ever increasing while the capabilities of current technology are being exhausted. This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project explores the possible static couplings between the electric and magnetic fields in new materials, such as hexagonal ferrites, by elucidating the connections between their electric, magnetic, and structural properties, and fine-tuning the materials using advanced material preparations. Integrated with the research, the educational objectives of this project are, to promote teaching undergraduate students fundamental physics by exposing them to cutting-edge research and by exploiting new student-centered pedagogical approaches, to mentor and inspire student researchers with systematic trainings for innovative research, and to engage K-12 students to stimulate their interests in science.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY 

Switching a magnetic dipole using an electric field (magnetoelectric memory effect) - an effect that can be a working principle of the next-generation technology for information processing and storage - is unfortunately rare in known materials and restricted to low temperature. This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project explores the magnetoelectric memory effect that is efficient and stable at high temperature, by the discovery of new materials or by tuning the properties of known materials experimentally. In particular, this project investigates the possible magnetoelectric memory effect in the materials that exhibit both improper ferroelectricity and improper ferromagnetism, such as hexagonal ferrites (h-RFeO3; R =Y, Ho, Lu). The specific research objectives of the proposed work are: 1) Elucidate the origin of the magnetic orderings in hexagonal ferrites. 2) Experimentally determine the magnetoelectric effect and identify the underlying mechanism in hexagonal ferrites. 3) Adjust the magnetic properties and the coupling between the magnetic and electric properties in hexagonal ferrites by tuning their structures using epitaxial thin film growth. Pulsed laser deposition method is employed to prepare single crystalline epitaxial thin film materials of tuned structures. The details of magnetic, electronic, and lattice structures are investigated using neutron scattering, x-ray spectroscopy, and x-ray diffraction respectively. The couplings between the electric and magnetic properties are studied by measuring the change of ferromagnetic properties in an electric field. Besides advancing the understanding in the magnetoelectric couplings in complex oxides in general, the success of the project may experimentally establish a new paradigm of magnetoelectric effect originated from improper ferroelectricity and improper ferromagnetism

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

This project studies coexistence of ferroelectricity and magnetic order and their coupling in hexagonal rare earth ferrites for next-generation information technological applications. Ferroelectricity is a material property describing the switchable ordering of dipole moments at the atomic scale which leads to macroscopic spontaneous polarization, while magnetic ordering describes the arrangement of atomic-scale magnetic dipole moments. The coexistence of ferroelectricity and magnetism is called multiferroicity; the coupling between the electric and magnetic orderings, called magnetoelectric coupling, is promising to be a working mechanism for energy-efficient information processing and storage. This project studies existing materials and explores new material aiming at understanding multiferroicity and magnetoelectric coupling and realizing these properties at high enough temperature for application.

This project also adopts an integrated education-research approach promoting the learning-by-design concept. A diverse population of researchers are mentored according to their cognition levels and the designed trajectory.

Intellectual Merit:

This project advanced our understanding on the ferroelectricity, magnetic order, and magnetoelectric coupling in the hexagonal rare earth ferrites as well as in related complex oxide materials.

  • For magnetism, we have elucidated that (1) the single-ion magnetic anisotropy, as a prerequisite for the weak ferromagnetism of hexagonal rare earth ferrites, originates from the structural distortion and the electronic configuration of iron ions; (2) the three-dimensional magnetic ordering is possible because the structural distortion breaks the symmetry which cancels the magnetic interaction between different atomic layers. Following the elucidation of the mechanism of magnetic ordering, we discovered hexagonal scandium ferrite with record-high magnetic ordering temperature in the material family of hexagonal rare earth ferrites.
  • For ferroelectricity, we have elucidated that (1) the compressive biaxial strain effect enhances the ferroelectric polarization; (2) because the ferroelectric order originates from the structural distortion, the spontaneous polarization persists down to the ultra-thin limit without a critical thickness where the spontaneous polarization disappears.
  • For the magnetoelectric coupling, we have demonstrated that the coupling of the bulk material is minimal due to the restriction of symmetry while the coupling is substantial at the ferroelectric domain walls due to the dramatically different scale of magnetic and ferroelectric domain walls.
  • We have also discovered the structural compatibility between hexagonal rare earth ferrites and spinel materials, making spinel great candidate for buffer layer and bottom electrode materials not only for studying fundamental properties but also for device fabrication.

Overall, fundamental understanding has been gained through this project, in terms of bulk properties and mechanisms, as well as of the possibility of tuning these properties in the form of thin films of controlled microstructures.

Broader Impacts:

Overall, the support of this project has been crucial for the PI to generate a broad impact in terms of research achievements, developing research-oriented teaching strategy, and outreaching to the public.

The fundamental understanding gained in ferroelectricity, magnetism, and magnetoelectric coupling highlights the effect of structural symmetry on the electric and magnetic properties of materials, which has a broad implication on all materials. The findings on spinel materials, including the novel conducting phase and the intrinsic exchange bias will have a broad impact on applications since the spinel materials are already widely used.

This project is critical for the PI to establish research-oriented teaching strategies. Based on the Bloom taxonomy, research and learning (teaching) are basically different stages of cognition that requires different thinking skills. Therefore, helping students progress through these stages, (from understanding, to applying, to analyzing, to evaluating, to creating) is the foundation of the teaching and mentoring strategy of the PI. Starting with helping student with proper self-conception, the research tasks are designed to practice at the current stage to advance to the next stage. For example, explaining, teaching, or presenting fundamental principles related to the experimental techniques, data analysis, material properties, and physical phenomena, have been a great practice for students on the understanding stage. Compiling experimental results and compare with previous results are practices on analyzing and evaluating. These practices and the awareness of the cognition stages have been shown effective for scaffolding students in research-oriented learning.

This project also supported the effort of the PI to outreach to the public on condensed matter and material physics research. The PI has hosted seven summer school interns who got exposure to the cutting-edge research. The principles in experimental design has also been communicated by the PI in Nebraska State Olympiad for five years.
